quizzes.question:
Fill in the blank to comment out the text:
[!raw!]
x = 8
{0} printing x
print(x)
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Comments[/h1]

[b]Comments [/b]are annotations to code used to make it easier to understand. They don't affect how code is run. 
In Python, a comment is created by inserting an [b]octothorpe [/b](otherwise known as a number sign or hash symbol: #). All text after it on that line is ignored.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="336"]x = 365
y = 7
[b]# this is a comment[/b]

print(x % y) [b]# find the remainder[/b]
[b]# print (x // y)[/b]
[b]# another comment[/b][/code]
[b]Result: [/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
1
>>>[/code]
[note]Python doesn't have general purpose multiline comments, as do programming languages such as C.[/note]

quizzes.question: Can a docstring contain multiple lines of text?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Docstrings[/h1]

[b]Docstrings[/b] (documentation strings) serve a similar purpose to comments, as they are designed to explain code. However, they are more specific and have a different syntax. They are created by putting a multiline string containing an explanation of the function below the [b]function's first line[/b].[code format="py" codeId="337"]def shout(word):
  [b]"""
  Print a word with an
  exclamation mark following it.
  """[/b]
  print(word + "!")
    
shout("spam")[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
spam!
>>>[/code]
[note]Unlike conventional comments, [b]docstrings [/b]are retained throughout the runtime of the program. This allows the programmer to inspect these comments at run time.[/note]
